{{Chembox | Verifiedfields = changed | verifiedrevid = 477189498 | ImageFile = 12-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid.png | ImageSize = 200px | IUPACName = (5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',12''S'',14''Z'')-12-Hydroxyicosa-5,8,10,14-tetraenoic acid | OtherNames = 12-HETE; 12(S)-HETE |Section1={{Chembox Identifiers | IUPHAR_ligand = 3404 | ChemSpiderID_Ref = {{chemspidercite|correct|chemspider}} | ChEBI_Ref = {{ebicite|correct|EBI}} | ChEBI = 34146 | ChemSpiderID = 4446279 | InChI = 1/C20H32O3/c1-2-3-4-5-10-13-16-19(21)17-14-11-8-6-7-9-12-15-18-20(22)23/h7-11,13-14,17,19,21H,2-6,12,15-16,18H2,1H3,(H,22,23)/b9-7-,11-8-,13-10-,17-14+/t19-/m0/s1 | InChIKey = ZNHVWPKMFKADKW-LQWMCKPYBD | SMILES1 = O=C(O)CCC\C=C/C/C=C\C=C\[C@@H](O)C\C=C/CCCCC | StdInChI_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChI = 1S/C20H32O3/c1-2-3-4-5-10-13-16-19(21)17-14-11-8-6-7-9-12-15-18-20(22)23/h7-11,13-14,17,19,21H,2-6,12,15-16,18H2,1H3,(H,22,23)/b9-7-,11-8-,13-10-,17-14+/t19-/m0/s1 | StdInChIKey_Ref = {{stdinchicite|correct|chemspider}} | StdInChIKey = ZNHVWPKMFKADKW-LQWMCKPYSA-N | CASNo_Ref = {{cascite|changed|??}} | CASNo = 54397-83-0 | PubChem = 5283155 | SMILES = CCCCC/C=C\C[C@@H](/C=C/C=C\C/C=C\CCCC(=O)O)O }} |Section2={{Chembox Properties | C=20 | H=32 | O=3 | Appearance = | Density = | MeltingPt = | BoilingPt = | Solubility = }} |Section3={{Chembox Hazards | MainHazards = | FlashPt = | AutoignitionPt = }} }}
'''12-Hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid''' ('''12-HETE''') is a derivative of the 20 carbon [[polyunsaturated fatty acid]], [[arachidonic acid]], containing a [[Hydroxyl]] residue at carbon 12 and a 5''Z'',''8Z'',10''E'',14''Z'' [[Cis–trans isomerism]] configuration (Z=cis, E=trans) in its four double bonds. It was first found as a product of [[arachidonic acid]] metabolism made by human and bovine platelets through their 12''S''-[[lipoxygenase]] (i.e. [[ALOX12]]) enzyme(s).<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 4215079 | pmc = 433780 | year = 1974 | author1 = Hamberg | first1 = M | title = Prostaglandin endoperoxides. Novel transformations of arachidonic acid in human platelets | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 71 | issue = 9 | pages = 3400–4 | last2 = Samuelsson | first2 = B | doi=10.1073/pnas.71.9.3400| bibcode = 1974PNAS...71.3400H }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 804329 | year = 1975 | author1 = Nugteren | first1 = D. H. | title = Arachidonate lipoxygenase in blood platelets | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 380 | issue = 2 | pages = 299–307 | doi=10.1016/0005-2760(75)90016-8}}</ref> However, the term 12-HETE is ambiquous in that it has been used to indicate not only the initially detected "S" [[stereoisomer]], 12''S''-hydroxy-5''Z'',''8Z'',10''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (12(''S'')-HETE or 12''S''-HETE), made by platelets, but also the later detected "R" stereoisomer, 12(''R'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',''8Z'',10''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (also termed 12(''R'')-HETE or 12''R''-HETE) made by other tissues through their 12''R''-lipoxygenase enzyme, [[ALOX12B]]. The two isomers, either directly or after being further metabolized, have been suggested to be involved in a variety of human physiological and pathological reactions. Unlike [[hormones]] which are secreted by cells, travel in the circulation to alter the behavior of distant cells, and thereby act as [[Endocrine signalling]] agents, these arachidonic acid metabolites act locally as [[Autocrine signalling]] and/or [[Paracrine signaling]] agents to regulate the behavior of their cells of origin or of nearby cells, respectively. In these roles, they may amplify or dampen, expand or contract cellular and tissue responses to disturbances.
== Production ==
In humans, [[Arachidonate 12-lipoxygenase]] (12-LO, 12-LOX, ALO12, or platelet type 12-lipoxygenase) is encoded by the [[ALOX12]] gene and expressed primarily in platelets and skin. ALOX12 metabolizes [[arachidonic acid]] almost exclusively to 12(''S'')-hydroperoxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',10''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (12(''S'')-HpETE or 12''S''-HpETE).<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | pmid = 12432922 | year = 2002 | author1 = Yoshimoto | first1 = T | title = Arachidonate 12-lipoxygenases | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 68–69 | pages = 245–62 | last2 = Takahashi | first2 = Y | doi=10.1016/s0090-6980(02)00034-5}}</ref> [[Arachidonate 15-lipoxygenase]]-1 (15-LO-1, 15-LOX-1, ALOX15), which is expressed in far more tissues that ALOX12, metabolizes arachidonic acid primarily to 15(''S'')-HpETE along with other metabolites of the [[15-Hydroxyicosatetraenoic acid]] family; during this metabolism, however, ALOX15 also forms 12(''S'')-HpETE as a minor product.<ref name="Prog Lipid Res 2010"/> Arachidonate 12-lipoxygenase, 12R type, also termed 12RLOX and encoded by the [[ALOX12B]] gene, is expressed primarily in skin and cornea; it metabolizes arachidonic acid to 12(''R'')-HpETE.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite journal | pmid = 8443245 | year = 1993 | author1 = Oliw | first1 = E. H. | title = Bis-Allylic hydroxylation of linoleic acid and arachidonic acid by human hepatic monooxygenases | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1166 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 258–63 | doi=10.1016/0005-2760(93)90106-j}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12664563 | year = 2002 | author1 = Schneider | first1 = C | title = Analysis of cyclooxygenase-substrate interactions using stereospecifically-labeled arachidonic acids | journal = Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology | volume = 507 | pages = 49–53 | last2 = Boeglin | first2 = W. E. | last3 = Brash | first3 = A. R. | doi = 10.1007/978-1-4615-0193-0_8 | isbn = 978-1-4613-4960-0 }}</ref> [[Cytochrome P450]] enzymes convert arachidonic acid to a variety of hydroperoxy, epoxy, and dihydroxy derivatives including racemic mixtures of 12(''S'')-HpETE and 12(''R'')-HpETE or 12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''R'')-HETE; the ''R'' stereoisomer predominates in these mixtures.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal | pmid = 9435160 | year = 1998 | author1 = Bylund | first1 = J | title = Cytochromes P450 with bisallylic hydroxylation activity on arachidonic and linoleic acids studied with human recombinant enzymes and with human and rat liver microsomes | journal = The Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics | volume = 284 | issue = 1 | pages = 51–60 | last2 = Kunz | first2 = T | last3 = Valmsen | first3 = K | last4 = Oliw | first4 = E. H. }}</ref><ref name="ReferenceC"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20941528 | pmc = 2962793 | year = 2010 | author1 = Panigrahy | first1 = D | title = Cytochrome P450-derived eicosanoids: The neglected pathway in cancer | journal = Cancer and Metastasis Reviews | volume = 29 | issue = 4 | pages = 723–35 | last2 = Kaipainen | first2 = A | last3 = Greene | first3 = E. R. | last4 = Huang | first4 = S | doi = 10.1007/s10555-010-9264-x }}</ref> The initial 12(''S'')-HpETE and 12(''R'')-HpETE products, regardless of their pathway of formation, are rapidly reduced to 12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''R'')-HETE, respectively, by ubiquitous cellular peroxidases, including in particular [[Glutathione peroxidase]]s<ref name="Pathophysiology of the hepoxilins">{{cite journal | pmid = 25240838 | year = 2015 | author1 = Pace-Asciak | first1 = C. R. | title = Pathophysiology of the hepoxilins | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1851 | issue = 4 | pages = 383–96 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2014.09.007 }}</ref> or, alternatively, are further metabolized as described below.
Sub-primate mammals, such as the mouse, rat, rabbit, cow, and pig, express platelet type 12-lipoxygenase but also a leukocyte type 12-lipoxygenase (also termed 12/15-lipoxygenase, 12/15-LOX or 12/15-LO) which is an [[ortholog]] of, and metabolically equivalent to, human 15-LO-1 in that it forms predominantly 15(''S'')-HpETE with 12(''S'')-HpETE as a minor product.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18258795 | year = 2008 | author1 = Collins | first1 = J. F. | title = Induction of arachidonate 12-lipoxygenase (Alox15) in intestine of iron-deficient rats correlates with the production of biologically active lipid mediators | journal = AJP: Gastrointestinal and Liver Physiology | volume = 294 | issue = 4 | pages = G948–62 | last2 = Hu | first2 = Z | last3 = Ranganathan | first3 = P. N. | last4 = Feng | first4 = D | last5 = Garrick | first5 = L. M. | last6 = Garrick | first6 = M. D. | last7 = Browne | first7 = R. W. | doi = 10.1152/ajpgi.00274.2007 }}</ref> Mice also express an epidermal type 15-lipoxygenase (e-12LO) which has 50.8% amino acid sequence identity to human 15-LOX-2 and 49.3% sequence indetity to mouse [[Arachidonate 8-lipoxygenase]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 9518531 | year = 1998 | author1 = Krieg | first1 = P | title = CDNA cloning of a 8-lipoxygenase and a novel epidermis-type lipoxygenase from phorbol ester-treated mouse skin | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1391 | issue = 1 | pages = 7–12 | last2 = Kinzig | first2 = A | last3 = Heidt | first3 = M | last4 = Marks | first4 = F | last5 = Fürstenberger | first5 = G | doi=10.1016/s0005-2760(97)00214-2}}</ref> Mouse e-12LO metabolizes arachidonic acid predominantly to 12(''S'')-HETE and to a lesser extent 15(''S'')-HETE.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11204741 | year = 2001 | author1 = McDonnell | first1 = M | title = Characterization of the murine epidermal 12/15-lipoxygenase | journal = Prostaglandins & Other Lipid Mediators | volume = 63 | issue = 3 | pages = 93–107 | last2 = Davis Jr | first2 = W | last3 = Li | first3 = H | last4 = Funk | first4 = C. D. | doi=10.1016/s0090-6980(00)00100-3}}</ref>
Sub-human primates, although not extensively examined, appear to have 12-lipoxygenase expression patterns that resemble those of sub-primate mammals or humans depending on the closeness of there genetic relateness to these species.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20106647 | year = 2010 | author1 = Johannesson | first1 = M | title = Cloning, purification and characterization of non-human primate 12/15-lipoxygenases | journal = Prostaglandins, Leukotrienes and Essential Fatty Acids | volume = 82 | issue = 2–3 | pages = 121–9 | last2 = Backman | first2 = L | last3 = Claesson | first3 = H. E. | last4 = Forsell | first4 = P. K. | doi = 10.1016/j.plefa.2009.11.006 }}</ref>
== Further metabolism ==
In human (and mouse) skin epidermis, 12(''R'')-HpETE is metabolized by Epidermis-type lipoxygenase, i.e. eLOX3 (encoded by the [[ALOXE3]] gene), to two products: a) a specific [[hepoxilin]], 8''R''-hydroxy-11''R'',12''R''-epoxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (i.e. 8''R''-hydroxy,11''R'',12''R''-epoxy-hepoxilin A3 or 8''R''-OH,11''R'',12''R''-epoxy-hepoxilin A3) and b) 12-oxo-5''Z'',''8Z'',10''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid (12-oxo-HETE, 12-oxoETE, 12-Keto-ETE, or 12-KETE); 8''R''-hydroxy,11''R'',12''R''-epoxy-hepoxilin A3 is further metabolized by soluble [[Epoxide hydrolase 2]] (sEH) to 8''R'',11''R'',12''R''-trihydroxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid.<ref name="J Biol Chem p 21">{{cite journal | pmid = 17652088 | year = 2007 | author1 = Valmsen | first1 = K | title = A critical role of non-active site residues on cyclooxygenase helices 5 and 6 in the control of prostaglandin stereochemistry at carbon 15 | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 282 | issue = 38 | pages = 28157–63 | last2 = Boeglin | first2 = W. E. | last3 = Järving | first3 = R | last4 = Järving | first4 = I | last5 = Varvas | first5 = K | last6 = Brash | first6 = A. R. | last7 = Samel | first7 = N | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M704950200 }}</ref> 12(''R'')-HpETE also spontaneously decomposes to a mixture of hepoxilins and trihydroxy-eicosatetraenoic acids that possess ''R'' or ''S'' hydroxy and epoxy residues at various sites while 8''R''-hydroxy,11''R'',12''R''-epoxy-hepoxilin A3 spontaneously decomposes to 8''R'',11''R'',12''R''-trihydroxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid.<ref name="J Biol Chem p 21"/> These decompositions may occur during tissue isolation procedures. Recent studies indicate that the metabolism by [[ALOXE3]] of the ''R'' stereoisomer of 12-HpETE made by [[ALOX12B]] and therefore possibly the ''S'' stereoisomer of 12-HpETE made by ALOX12 or ALOX15 is responsible for forming various hepoxilins in the epidermis of human and mouse skin and tongue and possibly other tissues.<ref name="Biochim Biophys Acta 2013. p 7">{{cite journal | pmid = 24021977 | pmc = 4116325 | year = 2014 | author1 = Muñoz-Garcia | first1 = A | title = The importance of the lipoxygenase-hepoxilin pathway in the mammalian epidermal barrier | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1841 | issue = 3 | pages = 401–8 | last2 = Thomas | first2 = C. P. | last3 = Keeney | first3 = D. S. | last4 = Zheng | first4 = Y | last5 = Brash | first5 = A. R. | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2013.08.020 }}</ref><ref name="Biochim Biophys Acta 2013">{{cite journal | pmid = 23954555 | year = 2014 | author1 = Krieg | first1 = P | title = The role of lipoxygenases in epidermis | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1841 | issue = 3 | pages = 390–400 | last2 = Fürstenberger | first2 = G | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2013.08.005 }}</ref>
Human skin metabolizes 12(''S'')-HpETE in reactions strictly analogous to those of 12(''R'')-HpETE; it metabolized 12(''S'')-HpETE by eLOX3 to 8''R''-hydroxy-11''S'',12''S''-epoxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid and 12-oxo-ETE, with the former product then being metabolized by sEH to 8''R'',11''S'',12''S''-trihydroxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid. 12(''S'')-HpETE also spontaneously decomposes to a mixture of hepoxilins and trihydroxy-eicosatetraenoic acids (trioxillins) that possess ''R'' or ''S'' hydroxy and ''R'',''S'' or ''S'',''R'' [[epoxide]] residues at various sites while 8''R''-hydroxy,11''S'',12''S''-epoxy-hepoxilin A3 spontaneously decomposes to 8''R'',11''S'',12''S''-trihydroxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatetraenoic acid.<ref name="J Biol Chem p 21"/>
In other tissues and animal species, numerous hepoxilins form but the hepoxilin synthase activity responsible for their formation is variable. (Hepoxilin A3 [8''R/S''-hydroxy-11,12-epoxy-5''Z'',9''E'',14''Z''-eicosatrienoic acid] and hepoxilin B3 [10(''R/S''-hydroxy-11,12-epxoy-5''Z'',8''Z'',14''Z''-eicosatrienoic acid] refer to a mixture of [[Diastereomers]] and⁄or [[Enantiomers]] derived from arachidonic acid.<ref name="Pathophysiology of the hepoxilins"/><ref name="Biochim Biophys Acta 2013. p 7"/>) Cultured RINm5F rat [[Insulinoma]] cells convert 12(''S'')-HpETE to hepoxilin A3 in a reaction that is completely dependent on, and co-localizes with, the cells' leukocyte type 12-LOX; furthermore, recombinant rat and porcine leukocyte type 12-LOX as well as human platelet type 12-LOX metabolize 12(''S'')-HpETE to hepoxylin A3.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15123652 | year = 2004 | author1 = Nigam | first1 = S | title = The rat leukocyte-type 12-lipoxygenase exhibits an intrinsic hepoxilin A3 synthase activity | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 28 | pages = 29023–30 | last2 = Patabhiraman | first2 = S | last3 = Ciccoli | first3 = R | last4 = Ishdorj | first4 = G | last5 = Schwarz | first5 = K | last6 = Petrucev | first6 = B | last7 = Kühn | first7 = H | last8 = Haeggström | first8 = J. Z. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M307576200 }}</ref> However, transfection of HEK293 human embryonic kidney cells with each of the 6 rat lipoxygenases, including rat eLOX3, found that hepoxilin B3 production required eLOX3; furthermore, the development of inflammation-induced tactile pain hypersensitivity (hyperesthesia; tactile [[Allodynia]]) in rats required eLOX3-dependent production of hepoxilin B3 by spinal tissue.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23382512 | pmc = 3633813 | year = 2013 | author1 = Gregus | first1 = A. M. | title = Systematic analysis of rat 12/15-lipoxygenase enzymes reveals critical role for spinal eLOX3 hepoxilin synthase activity in inflammatory hyperalgesia | journal = The FASEB Journal | volume = 27 | issue = 5 | pages = 1939–49 | last2 = Dumlao | first2 = D. S. | last3 = Wei | first3 = S. C. | last4 = Norris | first4 = P. C. | last5 = Catella | first5 = L. C. | last6 = Meyerstein | first6 = F. G. | last7 = Buczynski | first7 = M. W. | last8 = Steinauer | first8 = J. J. | last9 = Fitzsimmons | first9 = B. L. | last10 = Yaksh | first10 = T. L. | last11 = Dennis | first11 = E. A. | doi = 10.1096/fj.12-217414 }}</ref> Thus, the production of hepoxilins from 12(S)-HpETE may result from the intrinsic activity of platelet or leukocyte type 12-LOX's, require eLOX3, or even result from 12(''S'')-HpETE spontaneous (and perhaps artefactual) decomposition during isolation. The majority of reports on hepoxilin formation have not defined the pathways evolved.
Human and other mammalian cytochrome P450 enzymes convert 12(''S'')-HpETE to 12-oxo-ETE.
12-HETE (stereoisomer not determined), 12(''S'')-HETE, 12-oxo-ETE, hepoxilin B3, and trioxilin B3 are found in the ''sn''-2 position of phospholipids isolated from normal human epidermis and human psoriatic scales.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 118490 | year = 1979 | author1 = Stenson | first1 = W. F. | title = 12-L-hydroxy-5,8,10,14-eicosatetraenoic acid, a chemotactic fatty acid, is incorporated into neutrophil phospholipids and triglyceride | journal = Prostaglandins | volume = 18 | issue = 2 | pages = 285–92 | last2 = Parker | first2 = C. W. | doi=10.1016/0090-6980(79)90115-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11851887 | year = 2002 | author1 = Antón | first1 = R | title = Hepoxilin B3 and its enzymatically formed derivative trioxilin B3 are incorporated into phospholipids in psoriatic lesions | journal = Journal of Investigative Dermatology | volume = 118 | issue = 1 | pages = 139–46 | last2 = Camacho | first2 = M | last3 = Puig | first3 = L | last4 = Vila | first4 = L | doi = 10.1046/j.0022-202x.2001.01593.x }}</ref> This indicates that the metabolites are acylated into the ''sn''-2 position after being formed and/or directly produced by the metabolism of the arachidonic acid at the ''sn''-2 position of these phospholipids. These acylation reactions may sequester and thereby inactivate or store the metabolites for release during cell stimulation.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 7790387 | year = 1995 | author1 = Joulain | first1 = C | title = Esterification of 12(S)-hydroxy-5,8,10,14-eicosatetraenoic acid into the phospholipids of human peripheral blood mononuclear cells: Inhibition of the proliferative response | journal = Journal of Cellular Physiology | volume = 164 | issue = 1 | pages = 154–63 | last2 = Meskini | first2 = N | last3 = Anker | first3 = G | last4 = Lagarde | first4 = M | last5 = Prigent | first5 = A. F. | doi = 10.1002/jcp.1041640120 }}</ref>
12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''R'')-HETE are converted to 12-oxo-ETE by microsomal [[NAD+]]-dependent 12-hydroxyeicosanoid dehdrogenase in porcine polymophonuclear leukocytes; a similar pathway may be active in rabbit corneal epitheleum, cow corneal epitheleum, and mouse keratinocytes although this pathway has not been described in human tissues.<ref name="Biochim Biophys Acta 2014">{{cite journal | pmid = 25449650 | pmc = 5710736 | year = 2015 | author1 = Powell | first1 = W. S. | title = Biosynthesis, biological effects, and receptors of hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids (HETEs) and oxoeicosatetraenoic acids (oxo-ETEs) derived from arachidonic acid | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Molecular and Cell Biology of Lipids | volume = 1851 | issue = 4 | pages = 340–55 | last2 = Rokach | first2 = J | doi = 10.1016/j.bbalip.2014.10.008 }}</ref>
12-oxo-ETE is metabolised by cytoslic [[NADH]]-dependent 12-oxoeicosinoid Δ10-reductase to 12-oxo-5''Z'',8''Z'',14''Z''-eicosatreienoic acid (12-oxo-ETrE); 12-ketoreductase may then reduce this 12-oxo-ETrE to 12(''R'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',14''Z''-eicosatreienoic acid (12(''R'')-HETrE) and to a lesser extent 12(''S'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''Z'',14''Z''-eicosatreienoic acid (12(''S'')-HETrE).<ref name="Biochim Biophys Acta 2014"/>
== Receptor targets and mechanisms of action ==
The [[G protein-coupled receptor]], GPR31, cloned from [[PC3]] human prostate cancer cell line is a high affinity (Kd=4.8 nM) receptor for 12(''S'')-HETE; GPR31 does not bind 12(''R'')-HETE and has relatively little affinity for 5(''S'')-HETE or 15(''S'')-HETE.<ref name="J Biol Chem p 30">{{cite journal | pmid = 21712392 | pmc = 3190773 | year = 2011 | author1 = Guo | first1 = Y | title = Identification of the orphan G protein-coupled receptor GPR31 as a receptor for 12-(S)-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 286 | issue = 39 | pages = 33832–40 | last2 = Zhang | first2 = W | last3 = Giroux | first3 = C | last4 = Cai | first4 = Y | last5 = Ekambaram | first5 = P | last6 = Dilly | first6 = A. K. | last7 = Hsu | first7 = A | last8 = Zhou | first8 = S | last9 = Maddipati | first9 = K. R. | last10 = Liu | first10 = J | last11 = Joshi | first11 = S | last12 = Tucker | first12 = S. C. | last13 = Lee | first13 = M. J. | last14 = Honn | first14 = K. V. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M110.216564 }}</ref> GPR31 mRNA is expressed at low levels in several human cell lines including [[K562 cells]] (human myelogenous leukemia cell line), [[Jurkat cells]], (T lymphocye cell line), Hut78 cells (T cell lymphoma cell line), [[HEK 293 cells]] (primary embryonic kidney cell line), MCF7 cells (mammary adenocarcinoma cell line), and EJ cells (bladder carcinoma cell line). This mRNA appears to be more highly expressed in PC3 and [[DU145]] prostate cancer cell lines as well as in [[human umbilical vein endothelial cell]]s (HUVEC), [[human umbilical vein endothelial cell]]s (HUVEC), human brain microvascular endothelial cells (HBMEC), and human pulmonary aortic endothelial cells (HPAC).<ref name="J Biol Chem p 30"/> In PC-3 prostate cancer cells, GPR31 receptor mediates the action of 12(''S'')-HETE in activating the [[Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase]]/[[Extracellular signal-regulated kinases]]-1/2 pathway and [[NFκB]] pathway that lead to cell growth and other functions.<ref name="J Biol Chem p 30"/> Studies have not yet determined the role, if any, in GPR31 receptor in the action of 12(''S'')-HETE in other cell types.
A G protein-coupled receptor for the 5(''S''),12(''R'')-dihydroxy metabolite of aracidonic acid, [[Leukotriene B4]], vis., [[Leukotriene B4 receptor 2]] (BLT2), but not its [[Leukotriene B4 receptor]] 1, mediates responses to 12(''S'')-HETE, 12(''R'')-HETE, and 12-oxo-ETE in many cell types.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11278893 | year = 2001 | author1 = Yokomizo | first1 = T | title = Hydroxyeicosanoids bind to and activate the low affinity leukotriene B4 receptor, BLT2 | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 276 | issue = 15 | pages = 12454–9 | last2 = Kato | first2 = K | last3 = Hagiya | first3 = H | last4 = Izumi | first4 = T | last5 = Shimizu | first5 = T | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M011361200 }}</ref> Based on the effects of LTB4 receptor antagonists, for example, leukotriene B4 receptor 2 mediates: the rise in cytosolic Ca<sup>2+</sup> concentration (a key signal for cell activation) in human neutrophils<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10477044 | year = 1999 | author1 = Sarau | first1 = H. M. | title = In vitro and in vivo pharmacological characterization of SB 201993, an eicosanoid-like LTB4 receptor antagonist with anti-inflammatory activity | journal = Prostaglandins, Leukotrienes, and Essential Fatty Acids | volume = 61 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–64 | last2 = Foley | first2 = J. J. | last3 = Schmidt | first3 = D. B. | last4 = Martin | first4 = L. D. | last5 = Webb | first5 = E. F. | last6 = Tzimas | first6 = M. N. | last7 = Breton | first7 = J. J. | last8 = Chabot-Fletcher | first8 = M | last9 = Underwood | first9 = D. C. | last10 = Hay | first10 = D. W. | last11 = Kingsbury | first11 = W. D. | last12 = Chambers | first12 = P. A. | last13 = Pendrak | first13 = I | last14 = Jakas | first14 = D. R. | last15 = Sathe | first15 = G. M. | last16 = Van Horn | first16 = S | last17 = Daines | first17 = R. W. | last9 = Penning | first9 = T. D. | last10 = Yu | first10 = S | doi=10.1007/bf01534461}}</ref> triggered by the injection these metabolites into the skin of mice and guinea pigs, respectively; and an in vitro angiogenic response by [[Human umbilical vein endothelial cell]]s (HUVEC) and in vivo angiogenic response by mice to 12(''S'')-HETE.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 19286633 | year = 2009 | author1 = Kim | first1 = G. Y. | title = Role of the low-affinity leukotriene B4 receptor BLT2 in VEGF-induced angiogenesis | journal = Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology | volume = 29 | issue = 6 | pages = 915–20 | last2 = Lee | first2 = J. W. | last3 = Cho | first3 = S. H. | last4 = Seo | first4 = J. M. | last5 = Kim | first5 = J. H. | doi = 10.1161/ATVBAHA.109.185793 }}</ref> The BLT2 receptor, in contrast to the GPR31 receptor, appears to be expressed at a high level in a wide range of tissues including [[neutrophils]], [[eosinophils]], [[monocytes]], spleen, liver, and ovary.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11278893 | year = 2001 | author1 = Yokomizo | first1 = T | title = Hydroxyeicosanoids bind to and activate the low affinity leukotriene B4 receptor, BLT2 | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 276 | issue = 15 | pages = 12454–9 | last2 = Kato | first2 = K | last3 = Hagiya | first3 = H | last4 = Izumi | first4 = T | last5 = Shimizu | first5 = T | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M011361200 }}</ref> However, [[12-Hydroxyheptadecatrienoic acid]] (i.e. 12-(''S'')-hydroxy-5''Z'',8''E'',10''E''-heptadecatrienoic acid or 12-HHT), a product made when [[prostaglandin H2]] is metablized to [[Thromboxane A2]] by [[Thromboxane synthase]] or spontaneously rearranges non-enzymatically (see [[12-Hydroxyheptadecatrienoic acid]]) is the most potent BLT2 receptor agonist detected to date.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18378794 | pmc = 2292216 | year = 2008 | author1 = Okuno | first1 = T | title = 12(S)-Hydroxyheptadeca-5Z, 8E, 10E-trienoic acid is a natural ligand for leukotriene B4 receptor 2 | journal = The Journal of Experimental Medicine | volume = 205 | issue = 4 | pages = 759–66 | last2 = Iizuka | first2 = Y | last3 = Okazaki | first3 = H | last4 = Yokomizo | first4 = T | last5 = Taguchi | first5 = R | last6 = Shimizu | first6 = T | doi = 10.1084/jem.20072329 }}</ref> To clarify the role of BLT2 versus GPC31 receptors in responses to 12(''S'')-HETE, and the role(s) of LTB4, 12(''S'')-HETE, versus 12-HHT in BLT2-mediated responses, it will be necessary to determine: a) if leukotriene B4 interacts with the GPR31 receptor; b) if BLT2 receptor antagonists interfere with the GPR31 receptor; and c) the relative concentrations and availability of LTB4, 12(''S'')-HETE, and 12-HHT in tissues exhibiting BLT2-dependent responses. Ultimately, both receptors and all three ligands may prove to be responsible for some tissue responses in vivo.
12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''R'')-HETE bind to and act as [[Competitive antagonist]]s of the [[Thromboxane receptor]] which mediates the actions of [[Thromboxane A2]] and [[Prostaglandin H2]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 2169775 | year = 1990 | author1 = Mais | first1 = D. E. | title = Interaction of 5-HETE, 12-HETE, 15-HETE and 5,12-diHETE at the human platelet thromboxane A2/prostaglandin H2 receptor | journal = Eicosanoids | volume = 3 | issue = 2 | pages = 121–4 | last2 = Saussy Jr | first2 = D. L. | last3 = Magee | first3 = D. E. | last4 = Bowling | first4 = N. L. }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 1837628 | year = 1991 | author1 = Fonlupt | first1 = P | title = 12-HETE inhibits the binding of PGH2/TXA2 receptor ligands in human platelets | journal = Thrombosis Research | volume = 63 | issue = 2 | pages = 239–48 | last2 = Croset | first2 = M | last3 = Lagarde | first3 = M | doi=10.1016/0049-3848(91)90287-7}}</ref> This antagonistic activity was responsible for the ability of 12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''R'')-HETE to relax mouse mesenteric arteries pre-constricted with a thromboxane A2 mimetic, [[U46619]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23203967 | pmc = 3774504 | year = 2013 | author1 = Siangjong | first1 = L | title = Endothelial 12(S)-HETE vasorelaxation is mediated by thromboxane receptor inhibition in mouse mesenteric arteries | journal = AJP: Heart and Circulatory Physiology | volume = 304 | issue = 3 | pages = H382–92 | last2 = Gauthier | first2 = K. M. | last3 = Pfister | first3 = S. L. | last4 = Smyth | first4 = E. M. | last5 = Campbell | first5 = W. B. | doi = 10.1152/ajpheart.00690.2012 }}</ref>
12(''S'')-HETE binds with high affinity to a 50 [[kilodalton]] (Kda) subunit of a 650 kDa cytosolic and nuclear protein complex.<ref name="pmid10375396">{{cite journal | vauthors = Herbertsson H, Kühme T, Hammarström S | title = The 650-kDa 12(S)-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid binding complex: occurrence in human platelets, identification of hsp90 as a constituent, and binding properties of its 50-kDa subunit | journal = Archives of Biochemistry and Biophysics | volume = 367 | issue = 1 | pages = 33–8 | date = Jul 1999 | pmid = 10375396 | doi = 10.1006/abbi.1999.1233 }}</ref>
== Activities and possible clinical significance ==
===Inflammation and inflammatory diseases=== 12(''S'')-HpETE, 12(''R'')-HETE, racemic mixtures of these 12-HETEs, and/or 12-oxo-ETE stimulate: a) the directed migration ([[chemotaxis]]) of human, rat, and rabbit [[neutrophils]] as well as rabbit [[macrophages]];<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 367961 | year = 1977 | author1 = Sahu | first1 = S | title = Lipid chemotaxins isolated from culture filtrates of Escherichia coli and from oxidized lipids | journal = Inflammation | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 47–54 | last2 = Lynn | first2 = W. S. | doi=10.1007/bf00920874}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6247746 | year = 1980 | author1 = Goetzl | first1 = E. J. | title = Unique aspects of the modulation of human neutrophil function by 12-L-hydroperoxy-5,8,10,14-eicosatetraenoic acid | journal = Prostaglandins | volume = 19 | issue = 1 | pages = 71–85 | last2 = Hill | first2 = H. R. | last3 = Gorman | first3 = R. R. | doi=10.1016/0090-6980(80)90155-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 6251514 | year = 1980 | author1 = Palmer | first1 = R. M. | title = Chemokinetic activity of arachidonic and lipoxygenase products on leuocyctes of different species | journal = Prostaglandins | volume = 20 | issue = 2 | pages = 411–8 | last2 = Stepney | first2 = R. J. | last3 = Higgs | first3 = G. A. | last4 = Eakins | first4 = K. E. | doi=10.1016/s0090-6980(80)80058-x}}</ref> b) human neutrophils to adhere to each other (i.e. aggregate) and in cooperation with [[Tumor necrosis factor alpha]] or [[Platelet-activating factor]], to release their granule-bound enzymes;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 7258296 | pmc = 1903737 | year = 1981 | author1 = O'Flaherty | first1 = J. T. | title = Neutrophil-aggregating activity of monohydroxyeicosatetraenoic acids | journal = The American Journal of Pathology | volume = 104 | issue = 1 | pages = 55–62 | last2 = Thomas | first2 = M. J. | last3 = Lees | first3 = C. J. | last4 = McCall | first4 = C. E. }}</ref> c) the binding of human vascular epithelial cells to human monocytes;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16461778 | year = 2006 | author1 = Huber | first1 = J | title = Specific monocyte adhesion to endothelial cells induced by oxidized phospholipids involves activation of cPLA2 and lipoxygenase | journal = The Journal of Lipid Research | volume = 47 | issue = 5 | pages = 1054–62 | last2 = Fürnkranz | first2 = A | last3 = Bochkov | first3 = V. N. | last4 = Patricia | first4 = M. K. | last5 = Lee | first5 = H | last6 = Hedrick | first6 = C. C. | last7 = Berliner | first7 = J. A. | last8 = Binder | first8 = B. R. | last9 = Leitinger | first9 = N | doi = 10.1194/jlr.M500555-JLR200 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10073973 | year = 1999 | author1 = Honda | first1 = H. M. | title = Induction of monocyte binding to endothelial cells by MM-LDL: Role of lipoxygenase metabolites | journal = Arteriosclerosis, Thrombosis, and Vascular Biology | volume = 19 | issue = 3 | pages = 680–6 | last2 = Leitinger | first2 = N | last3 = Frankel | first3 = M | last4 = Goldhaber | first4 = J. A. | doi=10.1161/01.atv.19.3.680}}</ref> d) DNA synthesis and mitogenesis in the immortalized human keratinocyte cell line [[HaCaT]];<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17521953 | year = 2007 | author1 = Yoo | first1 = H | title = Insulin-like growth factor-II regulates the 12-lipoxygenase gene expression and promotes cell proliferation in human keratinocytes via the extracellular regulatory kinase and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase pathways | journal = The International Journal of Biochemistry & Cell Biology | volume = 39 | issue = 6 | pages = 1248–59 | last2 = Kim | first2 = S. J. | last3 = Kim | first3 = Y | last4 = Lee | first4 = H | last5 = Kim | first5 = T. Y. | doi = 10.1016/j.biocel.2007.04.009 }}</ref> and e) when injected in the skin of human volunteers, the extravasation and local accumulation of circulating blood neutrophils and mononuclear cells.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 3998504 | year = 1985 | author1 = Dowd | first1 = P. M. | last4 = Camp | first4 = R. D. | last5 = Greaves | first5 = M. W. | doi=10.1111/1523-1747.ep12273537}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 2813813 | year = 1989 | author1 = Wollard | first1 = P. L. | last8 = Bellner | first8 = L | doi = 10.1097/ICO.0b013e3182936915 }}</ref> Since BLT2 appears to mediate the responses of leukocytes to 12(''S'')-HpETE, 12(''S'')-HETE, 12(''R'')-HETE, and 12-oxo-ETE but GPR31 is expressed by various other cells (e.g. vascular endothelium) involved in inflammation, the pro-inflammatory actions of 12-HETE in humans may involve both types of G protein-coupled receptors.
===Itch perception=== 12(''S'')-HpETE and 12(''S'')-HETE induce itching responses when injected into the skin of mice; this has led to the suggestion that these metabolites contribute to the itching (i.e. clinical [[pruritus]]) which accompanies such conditions as [[atopic dermatitis]], [[contact dermatitis]], [[urticaria]], [[chronic renal failure]], and [[cholestasis]].<ref name="J Pharmacol 2008">{{cite journal | pmid = 18536755 | pmc = 2451041 | year = 2008 | author1 = Kim | first1 = H. J. | title = Involvement of the BLT2 receptor in the itch-associated scratching induced by 12-(S)-lipoxygenase products in ICR mice | journal = British Journal of Pharmacology | volume = 154 | issue = 5 | pages = 1073–8 | last2 = Kim | first2 = D. K. | last3 = Kim | first3 = H | last4 = Koh | first4 = J. Y. | last5 = Kim | first5 = K. M. | last6 = Noh | first6 = M. S. | last7 = Lee | first7 = S | last8 = Kim | first8 = S | last9 = Park | first9 = S. H. | last10 = Kim | first10 = J. J. | last11 = Kim | first11 = S. Y. | last12 = Lee | first12 = C. H. | doi = 10.1038/bjp.2008.220 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17112507 | year = 2007 | author1 = Kim | first1 = D. K. | title = 12(S)-HPETE induces itch-associated scratchings in mice | journal = European Journal of Pharmacology | volume = 554 | issue = 1 | pages = 30–3 | last2 = Kim | first2 = H. J. | last3 = Sung | first3 = K. S. | last4 = Kim | first4 = H | last5 = Cho | first5 = S. A. | last6 = Kim | first6 = K. M. | last7 = Lee | first7 = C. H. | last8 = Kim | first8 = J. J. | doi = 10.1016/j.ejphar.2006.09.057 }}</ref> Since it mediates 12(''S'')-HETE-induced itching in the mouse model,<ref name="J Pharmacol 2008"/> BLT2 rather than GPR31 may mediate human itch in these reactions.
===Cancer===
====Prostate cancer==== 12-HETE (stereoisomer not defined) is the dominant arachidonic acid metabolite in cultured [[PC3]] human prostate cancer cells and its levels in human prostate cancer tissue exceed by >9-fold its levels in normal human prostate tissue.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22895552 | pmc = 3982713 | year = 2012 | author1 = Yang | first1 = P | title = Arachidonic acid metabolism in human prostate cancer | journal = International Journal of Oncology | volume = 41 | issue = 4 | pages = 1495–503 | last2 = Cartwright | first2 = C. A. | last3 = Li | first3 = J | last4 = Wen | first4 = S | last5 = Prokhorova | first5 = I. N. | last6 = Shureiqi | first6 = I | last7 = Troncoso | first7 = P | last8 = Navone | first8 = N. M. | last9 = Newman | first9 = R. A. | last10 = Kim | first10 = J | doi = 10.3892/ijo.2012.1588 }}</ref> Furthermore, 12(''S'')-HETE a) increases the expression of [[Alpha-v beta-5]] cell surface adhesion molecule and associated with this the survival of cultured PC3 cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12874035 | year = 2003 | author1 = Pidgeon | first1 = G. P. | title = Overexpression of platelet-type 12-lipoxygenase promotes tumor cell survival by enhancing alpha(v)beta(3) and alpha(v)beta(5) integrin expression | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 63 | issue = 14 | pages = 4258–67 | last2 = Tang | first2 = K | last3 = Cai | first3 = Y. L. | last4 = Piasentin | first4 = E | last5 = Honn | first5 = K. V. }}</ref> b) promotes the phosphorylation of [[retinoblastoma protein]] to inhibit its [[tumor suppressor]] function while promoting the proliferation of cultured PC3 cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 17218785 | year = 2007 | author1 = Yang | first1 = P | title = Zyflamend-mediated inhibition of human prostate cancer PC3 cell proliferation: Effects on 12-LOX and Rb protein phosphorylation | journal = Cancer Biology & Therapy | volume = 6 | issue = 2 | pages = 228–36 | last2 = Cartwright | first2 = C | last3 = Chan | first3 = D | last4 = Vijjeswarapu | first4 = M | last5 = Ding | first5 = J | last6 = Newman | first6 = R. A. | doi=10.4161/cbt.6.2.3624}}</ref> c) stimulates PC3 cells to activate the [[Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase]]/[[extracellular signal-regulated kinases]]-1/2 pathway and the [[NFκB]] pathways that lead to cell proliferation;<ref name="J Biol Chem p 30"/> d) reverses the [[apoptosis]]-inducing (i.e. cell-killing) effect of pharmacologically inhibiting 12-LO in cultured [[DU145]] human prostate cancer cells;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11980674 | year = 2002 | author1 = Pidgeon | first1 = G. P. | title = Mechanisms controlling cell cycle arrest and induction of apoptosis after 12-lipoxygenase inhibition in prostate cancer cells | journal = Cancer Research | volume = 62 | issue = 9 | pages = 2721–7 | last2 = Kandouz | first2 = M | last3 = Meram | first3 = A | last4 = Honn | first4 = K. V. }}</ref> e) promotes the induction of [[cyclooxygenase-1]] and thereby the synthesis of this enzyme's growth-promoting arachidonic acid metabolite, [[PGE2]], in cultured PC3 and LNCaP human prostate cancer cells;<ref>PC3 and LNCaP</ref> and f) induces cultured PC3 cells to express [[Vascular endothelial growth factor]] (VEGF), a protein that stimulates the formation of the microvasclature which assists in the metastasis of cancer.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 16638750 | year = 2006 | author1 = Nie | first1 = D | title = Mechanisms regulating tumor angiogenesis by 12-lipoxygenase in prostate cancer cells | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 281 | issue = 27 | pages = 18601–9 | last2 = Krishnamoorthy | first2 = S | last3 = Jin | first3 = R | last4 = Tang | first4 = K | last5 = Chen | first5 = Y | last6 = Qiao | first6 = Y | last7 = Zacharek | first7 = A | last8 = Guo | first8 = Y | last9 = Milanini | first9 = J | last10 = Pages | first10 = G | last11 = Honn | first11 = K. V. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M601887200 }}</ref> These results suggest that the 12(''S'')-HETE made by prostate cancer tissues serves to promote the growth and spread of this cancer. Since it mediates the action of 12(''S'')-HETE in stimulating cultured PC3 cells to activate the [[Mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase]]/[[Extracellular signal-regulated kinases]]-1/2 pathway and [[NFκB]] pathways, the GPR31 receptor may contribute to the pro-malignant activity of 12(''S'')-HETE. However, LNCaP and PC3 cells also express BLT2 receptors; in LNCaP cells, BLT2 receptors are positively linked (i.e. stimulate the expression of) to the growth- and metastasis-promoting androgen receptor;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22426480 | year = 2012 | author1 = Lee | first1 = J. W. | title = Androgen receptor is up-regulated by a BLT2-linked pathway to contribute to prostate cancer progression | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 420 | issue = 2 | pages = 428–33 | last2 = Kim | first2 = G. Y. | last3 = Kim | first3 = J. H. | doi = 10.1016/j.bbrc.2012.03.012 }}</ref> in PC3 cells, BLT2 receptors stimulate the NF-κB pathway to inhibit the apoptosis caused by cell detachment from surfaces (i.e. [[Anoikis]];<ref name="pmid23986446">{{cite journal | pmid = 23986446 | pmc = 3798474 | year = 2013 | author1 = Lee | first1 = J. W. | title = Activation of the leukotriene B4 receptor 2-reactive oxygen species (BLT2-ROS) cascade following detachment confers anoikis resistance in prostate cancer cells | journal = Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 288 | issue = 42 | pages = 30054–63 | last2 = Kim | first2 = J. H. | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M113.481283 }}</ref> and, in BLT2-overexpressing PWR-1E non-malignant prostate cells, 12(''S'')-HETE diminish anoikis-induced apoptosis.<ref name="pmid23986446"/> ith occurs. Thus, the role of 12(''S'')-HETE in human prostate cancer, if any, may involve its activation of one or both of the GPR31 and BLT2 receptors.
====Other cancers==== Preclinical laboratory studies analogous to those conducted on the pro-malignant effects of 12(''S'')-HETE and growth-inhibiting effects of blocking 12-HETE production in cultured prostate cancer cell lines, have implicated 12-HETE (stereoisomer sometimes undefined) in cancer cell lines from various other human tissues including those from the liver,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22484589 | year = 2012 | author1 = Xu | first1 = X. M. | title = Inhibition of 12-lipoxygenase reduces proliferation and induces apoptosis of hepatocellular carcinoma cells in vitro and in vivo | journal = Hepatobiliary & Pancreatic Diseases International : HBPD INT | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 193–202 | last2 = Yuan | first2 = G. J. | last3 = Deng | first3 = J. J. | last4 = Guo | first4 = H. T. | last5 = Xiang | first5 = M | last6 = Yang | first6 = F | last7 = Ge | first7 = W | last8 = Chen | first8 = S. Y. | doi=10.1016/s1499-3872(12)60147-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24661807 | pmc = 4169337 | year = 2014 | author1 = Fitian | first1 = A. I. | title = Integrated metabolomic profiling of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis C cirrhosis through GC/MS and UPLC/MS-MS | journal = Liver International | volume = 34 | issue = 9 | pages = 1428–44 | last2 = Nelson | first2 = D. R. | last3 = Liu | first3 = C | last4 = Xu | first4 = Y | last5 = Ararat | first5 = M | last6 = Cabrera | first6 = R | doi = 10.1111/liv.12541 }}</ref> intestinal epithelium,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 8679690 | year = 1996 | author1 = Bortuzzo | first1 = C | title = The effect of leukotrienes B and selected HETEs on the proliferation of colon cancer cells | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1300 | issue = 3 | pages = 240–6 | last2 = Hanif | first2 = R | last3 = Kashfi | first3 = K | last4 = Staiano-Coico | first4 = L | last5 = Shiff | first5 = S. J. | last6 = Rigas | first6 = B | doi=10.1016/0005-2760(96)00003-3}}</ref><ref name="Int J Biochem Cell Biol 2013">{{cite journal | pmid = 23685077 | year = 2013 | author1 = Cabral | first1 = M | title = Role of arachidonic acid metabolites on the control of non-differentiated intestinal epithelial cell growth | journal = The International Journal of Biochemistry & Cell Biology | volume = 45 | issue = 8 | pages = 1620–8 | last2 = Martín-Venegas | first2 = R | last3 = Moreno | first3 = J. A. | title = Lipoxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism in growth control of tumor cells of different type | journal = Biochemistry. Biokhimiia | volume = 70 | issue = 12 | pages = 1396–403 | last2 = Gudkova | first2 = M. V. | last3 = Pavlova | first3 = O. M. | last4 = Oreshkin | first4 = A. E. | last5 = Myasishcheva | first5 = N. V. | doi=10.1007/s10541-005-0275-0}}</ref> breast,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12200139 | year = 2002 | author1 = Tong | first1 = W. G. | title = The mechanisms of lipoxygenase inhibitor-induced apoptosis in human breast cancer cells | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 296 | issue = 4 | pages = 942–8 | last2 = Ding | first2 = X. Z. | last3 = Adrian | first3 = T. E. | doi=10.1016/s0006-291x(02)02014-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21629247 | pmc = 3142797 | year = 2011 | author1 = Vonach | first1 = C | title = NF-κB mediates the 12(S)-HETE-induced endothelial to mesenchymal transition of lymphendothelial cells during the intravasation of breast carcinoma cells | journal = British Journal of Cancer | volume = 105 | issue = 2 | pages = 263–71 | last2 = Viola | first2 = K | last3 = Giessrigl | first3 = B | last4 = Huttary | first4 = N | last5 = Raab | first5 = I | last6 = Kalt | first6 = R | last7 = Krieger | first7 = S | last8 = Vo | first8 = T. P. | last9 = Madlener | first9 = S | last10 = Bauer | first10 = S | last11 = Marian | first11 = B | last12 = Hämmerle | first12 = M | last13 = Kretschy | first13 = N | last14 = Teichmann | first14 = M | last15 = Hantusch | first15 = B | last16 = Stary | first16 = S | last17 = Unger | first17 = C | last18 = Seelinger | first18 = M | last19 = Eger | first19 = A | last20 = Mader | first20 = R | last21 = Jäger | first21 = W | last22 = Schmidt | first22 = W | last23 = Grusch | first23 = M | last24 = Dolznig | first24 = H | last25 = Mikulits | first25 = W | last26 = Krupitza | first26 = G | doi = 10.1038/bjc.2011.194 }}</ref> skin ([[Melanoma]],<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12394183 | year = 2002 | author1 = Winer | first1 = I | title = Expression of 12-lipoxygenase as a biomarker for melanoma carcinogenesis | journal = Melanoma Research | volume = 12 | issue = 5 | pages = 429–34 | last2 = Normolle | first2 = D. P. | last3 = Shureiqi | first3 = I | last4 = Sondak | first4 = V. K. | last5 = Johnson | first5 = T | last6 = Su | first6 = L | last7 = Brenner | first7 = D. E. | doi=10.1097/00008390-200209000-00003}}</ref> ovary,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 21442472 | year = 2011 | author1 = Guo | first1 = A. M. | title = Role of 12-lipoxygenase in regulation of ovarian cancer cell proliferation and survival | journal = Cancer Chemotherapy and Pharmacology | volume = 68 | issue = 5 | pages = 1273–83 | last2 = Liu | first2 = X | last3 = Al-Wahab | first3 = Z | last4 = Maddippati | first4 = K. R. | last5 = Ali-Fehmi | first5 = R | last6 = Scicli | first6 = A. G. | last7 = Munkarah | first7 = A. R. | doi = 10.1007/s00280-011-1595-y }}</ref> pancrease,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10405349 | year = 1999 | author1 = Ding | first1 = X. Z. | title = Lipoxygenase inhibitors abolish proliferation of human pancreatic cancer cells | journal = Biochemical and Biophysical Research Communications | volume = 261 | issue = 1 | pages = 218–23 | last2 = Iversen | first2 = P | last3 = Cluck | first3 = M. W. | last4 = Knezetic | first4 = J. A. | last5 = Adrian | first5 = T. E. | doi = 10.1006/bbrc.1999.1012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11745456 | year = 2001 | author1 = Ding | first1 = X. Z. | title = 12-lipoxygenase metabolite 12(S)-HETE stimulates human pancreatic cancer cell proliferation via protein tyrosine phosphorylation and ERK activation | journal = International Journal of Cancer | volume = 94 | issue = 5 | pages = 630–6 | last2 = Tong | first2 = W. G. | last3 = Adrian | first3 = T. E. | doi = 10.1002/ijc.1527 }}</ref> and possibly bladder.<ref name="Exp Mol Med 2011">{{cite journal | pmid = 21252614 | pmc = 3068295 | year = 2011 | author1 = Seo | first1 = J. M. | title = Up-regulation of BLT2 is critical for the survival of bladder cancer cells | journal = Experimental & Molecular Medicine | volume = 43 | issue = 3 | pages = 129–37 | last2 = Cho | first2 = K. J. | last3 = Kim | first3 = E. Y. | last4 = Choi | first4 = M. H. | last5 = Chung | first5 = B. C. | last6 = Kim | first6 = J. H. | doi = 10.3858/emm.2011.43.3.014 }}</ref> These studies implicate the interaction of 12-HETE with BLT2 receptors in intestinal epithelium cancer cells,<ref name="Int J Biochem Cell Biol 2013"/> and BLT2 receptors in breast, ovary, pancreas, and bladder cancer cells.<ref name="Exp Mol Med 2011"/><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 23977445 | pmc = 3744015 | year = 2013 | author1 = Cho | first1 = N. K. | title = BLT2 is a pro-tumorigenic mediator during cancer progression and a therapeutic target for anti-cancer drug development | journal = American Journal of Cancer Research | volume = 3 | issue = 4 | pages = 347–55 | last2 = Joo | first2 = Y. C. | last3 = Wei | first3 = J. D. | last4 = Park | first4 = J. I. | last5 = Kim | first5 = J. H. }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 18781173 | pmc = 2567081 | year = 2008 | author1 = Hennig | first1 = R | title = BLT2 is expressed in PanINs, IPMNs, pancreatic cancer and stimulates tumour cell proliferation | journal = British Journal of Cancer | volume = 99 | issue = 7 | pages = 1064–73 | last2 = Osman | first2 = T | last3 = Esposito | first3 = I | last4 = Giese | first4 = N | last5 = Rao | first5 = S. M. | last6 = Ding | first6 = X. Z. | last7 = Tong | first7 = W. G. | last8 = Büchler | first8 = M. W. | last9 = Yokomizo | first9 = T | last10 = Friess | first10 = H | last11 = Adrian | first11 = T. E. | doi = 10.1038/sj.bjc.6604655 }}</ref> While the studies on these tissues have not been as frequent or diverse as those on prostate cancer cell lines, they are suggested to indicate that 12-HETE contributes to the growth or spread of the corresponding cancer in humans.
===Diabetes=== 12(S)-HETE, 12(''S'')-HpETE, and with far less potency 12(''R'')-HETE reduced insulin secretion and caused apoptosis in cultured human pancreatic [[insulin]]-secreting [[Beta cell]] lines and prepared [[Pancreatic islets]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15729574 | year = 2005 | author1 = Chen | first1 = M | title = Activation of 12-lipoxygenase in proinflammatory cytokine-mediated beta cell toxicity | journal = Diabetologia | volume = 48 | issue = 3 | pages = 486–95 | last2 = Yang | first2 = Z. D. | last3 = Smith | first3 = K. M. | last4 = Carter | first4 = J. D. | last5 = Nadler | first5 = J. L. | doi = 10.1007/s00125-005-1673-y }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 20089617 | pmc = 2840856 | year = 2010 | author1 = Ma | first1 = K | title = 12-Lipoxygenase Products Reduce Insulin Secretion and {beta}-Cell Viability in Human Islets | journal = The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism | volume = 95 | issue = 2 | pages = 887–93 | last2 = Nunemaker | first2 = C. S. | last3 = Wu | first3 = R | last4 = Chakrabarti | first4 = S. K. | last5 = Taylor-Fishwick | first5 = D. A. | last6 = Nadler | first6 = J. L. | doi = 10.1210/jc.2009-1102 }}</ref> [[TNFα]], [[IL-1β]], and [[IFNγ]] also reduced insulin secretion in cultured human pancreatic INS-1 beta cells, apparently by inducing the expression of [[NOX1]] (NADPH oxidase 1) and thereby to the production of cell-toxic [[Reactive oxygen species]]; these cytokine effects were completely dependent on 12-lipoxygenase and mimicked by 12(''S'')-HETE but not 12(''R'')-HETE.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 22502743 | year = 2012 | author1 = Weaver | first1 = J. R. | title = Integration of pro-inflammatory cytokines, 12-lipoxygenase and NOX-1 in pancreatic islet beta cell dysfunction | journal = Molecular and Cellular Endocrinology | volume = 358 | issue = 1 | pages = 88–95 | last2 = Holman | first2 = T. R. | last3 = Imai | first3 = Y | last4 = Jadhav | first4 = A | last5 = Kenyon | first5 = V | last6 = Maloney | first6 = D. J. | last7 = Nadler | first7 = J. L. | last8 = Rai | first8 = G | last9 = Simeonov | first9 = A | last10 = Taylor-Fishwick | first10 = D. A. | doi = 10.1016/j.mce.2012.03.004 }}</ref> 12-lipoxygenase-[[knockout]] mice (i.e., mice genetically manipulated to remove the Alox12 [i.e. 12-lipoxygenase gene, see [[lipoxygenase#mouse lipoxygenases]]) are resistant to '''a)''' [[streptozotocin]]-induced, '''b)''' high fat diet-induced, and '''c)''' autoimmune-induced diabetes.<ref name="Prog Lipid Res 2010">{{cite journal | pmid = 20970452 | pmc = 3012140 | year = 2011 | author1 = Dobrian | first1 = A. D. | title = Functional and pathological roles of the 12- and 15-lipoxygenases | journal = Progress in Lipid Research | volume = 50 | issue = 1 | pages = 115–31 | last2 = Lieb | first2 = D. C. | last3 = Cole | first3 = B. K. | last4 = Taylor-Fishwick | first4 = D. A. | last5 = Chakrabarti | first5 = S. K. | last6 = Nadler | first6 = J. L. | doi = 10.1016/j.plipres.2010.10.005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 10330425 | pmc = 408453 | year = 1999 | author1 = Bleich | first1 = D | title = Resistance to type 1 diabetes induction in 12-lipoxygenase knockout mice | journal = Journal of Clinical Investigation | volume = 103 | issue = 10 | pages = 1431–6 | last2 = Chen | first2 = S | last3 = Zipser | first3 = B | last4 = Sun | first4 = D | last5 = Funk | first5 = C. D. | last6 = Nadler | first6 = J. L. | doi = 10.1172/JCI5241 }}</ref> Further studies in animal models suggest that the 12''S''-HETE made by pancreatic beta cells (or possibly [[alpha cells]] or other cell types indigenous to or invading the pancreatic islands) orchestrate a local immune response that results in the injury and, when extreme, death of beta cells.<ref name="Prog Lipid Res 2010"/> These results suggest that the 12-lipoxygenase-12S-HETE pathway is one factor contributing to immunity-based [[type I diabetes]] as well as low insulin output [[type II diabetes]].
===Blood pressure=== 12(''S'')-HETE and 12(''S'')-HpETE stimulate the dilation of rat mesenteric arteries;<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 15626691 | year = 2005 | author1 = Zhou | first1 = W | title = Impaired arachidonic acid-mediated dilation of small mesenteric arteries in Zucker diabetic fatty rats | journal = AJP: Heart and Circulatory Physiology | volume = 288 | issue = 5 | pages = H2210–8 | last2 = Wang | first2 = X. L. | last3 = Kaduce | first3 = T. L. | last4 = Spector | first4 = A. A. | last5 = Lee | first5 = H. C. | doi = 10.1152/ajpheart.00704.2004 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 12490584 | year = 2003 | author1 = Miller | first1 = A. W. | title = Arachidonic acid-induced vasodilation of rat small mesenteric arteries is lipoxygenase-dependent | journal = Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics | volume = 304 | issue = 1 | pages = 139–44 | last2 = Katakam | first2 = P. V. | last3 = Lee | first3 = H. C. | last4 = Tulbert | first4 = C. D. | last5 = Busija | first5 = D. W. | last6 = Weintraub | first6 = N. L. | doi = 10.1124/jpet.102.041780 }}</ref> 12(''S'')-HETE stimulates the dilation of coronary microvessels in pigs and the [[mesenteric arteries]] of mice,<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11158968 | year = 2001 | author1 = Zink | first1 = M. H. | title = 12-lipoxygenase in porcine coronary microcirculation: Implications for coronary vasoregulation | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Heart and Circulatory Physiology | volume = 280 | issue = 2 | pages = H693–704 | last2 = Oltman | first2 = C. L. | last3 = Lu | first3 = T | last4 = Katakam | first4 = P. V. | last5 = Kaduce | first5 = T. L. | last6 = Lee | first6 = H | last7 = Dellsperger | first7 = K. C. | last8 = Spector | first8 = A. A. | last9 = Myers | first9 = P. R. | last10 = Weintraub | first10 = N. L. | doi=10.1152/ajpheart.2001.280.2.h693}}</ref> one or more of these three metabolites are implicated in the vasolilation of rat [[basilar artery]],<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 11404300 | year = 2001 | author1 = Faraci | first1 = F. M. | title = Arachidonate dilates basilar artery by lipoxygenase-dependent mechanism and activation of K(+) channels | journal = American Journal of Physiology. Regulatory, Integrative and Comparative Physiology | volume = 281 | issue = 1 | pages = R246–53 | last2 = Sobey | first2 = C. G. | last3 = Chrissobolis | first3 = S | last4 = Lund | first4 = D. D. | last5 = Heistad | first5 = D. D. | last6 = Weintraub | first6 = N. L. }}</ref> 12(''R'')-HETE and to a slightly lesser extent 12(''S'')-HETE constrict the renal artery of dogs<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 1908641 | year = 1991 | author1 = Ma | first1 = Y. H. | title = Effects of 12-HETE on isolated dog renal arcuate arteries | journal = The American Journal of Physiology | volume = 261 | issue = 2 Pt 2 | pages = H451–6 | last2 = Harder | first2 = D. R. | last3 = Clark | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Roman | first4 = R. J. }}</ref> and 12-HETE (stereoisomer undetermined) is implicated in the angiotensin II-induced arterial hypertension response of human placenta.<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 9052898 | year = 1997 | author1 = Kisch | first1 = E. S. | title = Role of the lipoxygenase pathway in angiotensin II-induced vasoconstriction in the human placenta | journal = Hypertension | volume = 29 | issue = 3 | pages = 796–801 | last2 = Jaffe | first2 = A | last3 = Knoll | first3 = E | last4 = Stern | first4 = N | doi=10.1161/01.hyp.29.3.796}}</ref> The vasodilating effect on mouse mesenteric arteries appears due to 12''S''-HETE's ability to act as a [[Thromboxane receptor]] antagonist and thereby block the vasoconstricting actions of [[thromboxane A2]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 24685839 | year = 2014 | author1 = Porro | first1 = B | title = Analysis, physiological and clinical significance of 12-HETE: A neglected platelet-derived 12-lipoxygenase product | journal = Journal of Chromatography B | volume = 964 | pages = 26–40 | last2 = Songia | first2 = P | last3 = Squellerio | first3 = I | last4 = Tremoli | first4 = E | last5 = Cavalca | first5 = V | doi = 10.1016/j.jchromb.2014.03.015 }}</ref> These results indicate that the cited metabolites have dilating or constricting effects that depend on the arterial vascular site and or species of animal examined; their role in human blood pressure regulation is unclear.
=== Toxic effects === Excessive 12-HETE production is implicated in [[psoriasis]].<ref name="pmid 6305285" />
